botanical_details.genus: Malus are small to medium-sized deciduous trees with showy flowers in spring and ornamental or edible fruit in autumn; some have good autumn foliage colour

how_to_grow.cultivation: Prefers a deep, fertile, moist but well-drained, neutral soil in a sheltered, sunny position. Will not thrive on very acid soils, shallow chalk soils or with shade for more than half the day. Thin fruit in late spring or early summer to improve size and quality. See apple cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by chip budding or grafting onto a clonal rootstock for fruit. The rootstock used will largely determine the vigour of the tree. Fruit grown from pips will not resemble the parent
how_to_grow.pruning: Prune according to chosen training method. See apple pruning
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by aphids, including woolly aphid and rosy apple aphid, fruit tree red spider mite, codling moth and other caterpillars
how_to_grow.diseases: Average resistance to apple scab and powdery mildews, susceptible to apple canker. Apples are also susceptible to brown rot, honey fungus and blossom wilt
